Saying Bitcoin can be bigger than the impact of the internet is absurd... Bitcoin is a subset of the internet's impact, and thus every measure of Bitcoin's effect must also be counted in the internet's bucket, too. Blockchains are one of the internet's most important derrivatives

The tall kids aren't themselves part of the short parents. Bitcoin is part of the internet... not a separate thing. Bitcoin is a branch of internet technology, like VoIP, websites, email, and Netflix.
Bitcoin bigger than the internet is hyperbole, while "to the moon" is a metaphor.
Then why wouldn't the internet also evolve? Quantum tech would change both the internet and bitcoin.

Changing information (internet) enabled and caused the economics of finance to change. This is my point: the internet caused/enabled/resulted in Bitcoin happening, as one subset of its consequences. Thus, Internet is more consequential than Bitcoin, because it includes Bitcoin
Then they should say that, instead of using hyperbole. Bitcoin doesn't need exaggeration, it is powerful and impactful enough.

I cringe whenever I hear someone say "Bitcoin will be bigger than the internet!" This is impossible and silly. Bitcoin is itself a branch and consequence of the internet, thus no matter how big it gets, the internet is always bigger.

6/ Refusing to recognize the power of the law, and refusing to recognize the power of # crypto, are both dead ends. As with most things in life, the truth is somewhere in-between.

5/ As I've said before, the # crypto community needs to find ways to openly & transparently collaborate with the regulators, as much as that may grate many libertarian roots:https://twitter.com/cburniske/status/978984450083127296 …

4/ In the cases where it appears # crypto would have to contort itself to meet outdated laws in a way that is net negative for society, then it is less the technology that needs to change and more the law.
3/ A future challenge is how do we in # crypto work with regulators, applying existing laws where applicable & fair for society, without bending the technology over backwards to meet outdated laws.
2/ The regulators, then, have already accomplished one big goal of signaling to the # crypto-community that rules & regulations cannot be an afterthought, but part of the planning process.
1/ Nearly every new # crypto team I encounter is now explicitly talking about the SEC, CFTC, etc and how to handle regulation. If they're not, it's because the team is avoiding the US altogether.
